stem: A 52-year-old client with chest pain is admitted to the ICU. Based on the provided Serial 12-Lead Localization & Hemodynamic Log and Standing Orders, which medication is most dangerous to administer to this client?

rationale.correct: This client is experiencing an Inferior MI with Right Ventricular (RV) involvement, as evidenced by ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF and V4R, plus JVD and clear lungs. In RV MI, the right side of the heart is weak and dependent on 'Preload' (venous return) to push blood through the lungs. Nitroglycerin is a potent preload reducer (venodilator); if given, it will cause a catastrophic drop in cardiac output and profound hypotension. This patient needs 'Volume, not Vasodilators'.
clinicalPearls: Inferior MI (II, III, aVF) = 40% chance of RV involvement.
RV MI Triad: Hypotension, JVD, and Clear Lungs. (The blood is stuck behind the weak right heart).
Morphine should also be used with extreme caution for the same reasons (venodilation).

questionTrap.trap: Thinking Nitroglycerin is ALWAYS the first-line treatment for chest pain.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Check the EKG leads and the lungs. If leads II, III, aVF are involved AND the lungs are clear (no left-heart failure), DO NOT give nitrates. The patient needs fluid to 'push' blood through the lazy right ventricle.

mnemonic.title: Right-Side Rules
mnemonic.expansion: Bottom leads (II, III, aVF). JVD + Clear Lungs. NO Nitrates. Fill the tank (Fluids).

exhibits.title: Serial 12-Lead EKG
exhibits.content: Current Findings: ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. ST-segment elevation also noted in V4R (Right-sided lead view). ST-depression in leads I and aVL.

exhibits.title: Standing Cardiac Orders
exhibits.content:
1. Morphine 2mg IV PRN pain.
2. Nitroglycerin 0.4mg SL every 5 mins PRN pain.
3. IV Normal Saline 500 mL bolus PRN hypotension.
4. Aspirin 325mg PO chewed now.
